title: Towns Named After Nations
name: Towns Named After Nations

properties.name: Angola (Indiana)
properties.description: Posted by HiveAngola, IndianaWe are one of the fastest growing areas in Indiana. Our popularity is a combination of 101 lakes, Pokagon State Park, Tri-State University, a nationally recognized K-12 school system, and a hard working, well-trained work force. We are a community looking to the future. We have begun implementation of a high speed fiber optic network throughout our City. Both of our industrial parks offer multiple providers of high speed Internet and both offer point to point direct fiber optic connections. In addition to our Internet Service Providers and fiber optic backbone, Angola also offers access to a high speed wireless data network available at nearly every location inside the City limits which is hosted and managed by The Indiana Data Center. Whatever type of network or high speed connection you or your business might be looking for, our City has a solution that will work for you. Our nationally recognized Tri-State University, and all that it offers, helps make a community our size unique. We are truly at the "Crossroads of America" with US 20, I-69, and the Indiana Toll Road intersecting in our County. Please contact us with any questions you have about our beautiful city or Steuben County. Sincerely, Richard M. Hickman Mayor Of Angola

properties.name: Bolivia (North Carolina)
properties.description: Posted by Hivebolivia, ncThe population was 148 at the 2000 census.

properties.name: China (Texas)
properties.description: Posted by Hivechina, texasIt is named for the "China Berry" trees that were native to the area but have all but gone extinct today. In fact, perhaps some of the only examples you may find of the trees in the area are in the front lawn of China Elementary. The two trees were transplanted in the mid 90\'s, and are steadily growing. China has an annual festival named after the trees, the China Berry Festival, to celebrate the city\'s people in a time of coming together.

properties.name: Cuba (Kansas)
properties.description: Posted by HiveCuba, KansasPronunced KU-buh, this mini Czech republic town of 200 has an annual Rock-a-Thon in March that isn\'t about music, but about rocking chairs! They rock for 24 hours straight to raise money for community events. The local grocery is where you can watch homemade bologna and jaternice\' (an ethnic Czech food) being made. For more information about Cuba, KS, call the city office at 785-729-3861.

properties.name: Denmark (Maine)
properties.description: Posted by BaostarDenmark, MaineDenmark is a town in Oxford County, Maine, United States, but the name is originally from a country in Scandinavia.

properties.name: Greece (New York)
properties.description: Posted by HiveGreece, NYThis city rests on Lake Ontario. In 1890, Eastman Kodak Co. built a plant here, but the city of Rochester annexed the area as Kodak Park in 1916. This is a bit of town history from the town\'s own city government website. Long the home of the Seneca Indians, the area which would become the Town of Greece was first visited by the French explorer LaSalle in 1669. This area would be witness to numerous troop movements over the next century as the French and English fought for control of North America. The Indian trail on the Ridge became the roadway along which English troops under General John Prideaux marched against the French at Fort Niagara. Later this same trail would carry pioneers and settlers westward. The first permanent settlement was established in 1792 along the west side of the Genesee River at King\'s Landing, later to be named Hanford Landing. With the establishment of the Port of the Genesee by President Thomas Jefferson in 1805, trade from the Great Lakes began to pour in. With access to Lake Ontario, the Genesee River, Ridge Road and later the Erie Canal, the Town became a transportation hub and a major supplier of farm produce to the new and growing nation. Originally called Northampton, the Town of Greece was established by the New York State Legislature on March 22, 1822. Its name was chosen because of the current wave of sympathy toward the Greeks who were then fighting for independence from Turkish rule. The Town seat was named Charlotte for the daughter of Colonel Troup, the land agent for an English estate which owned much of western New York at the time. Charlotte itself was incorporated as a village in 1869, and was part of Greece until 1916 when it was annexed to the City of Rochester as the 23rd Ward. Agriculture would remain the dominant enterprise in Greece until the twentieth century, when Eastman Kodak Company would become the major industrial employer in the region. Most of the Town\'s growth has occurred after World War II with the population exceeding 94,000 in 2000. The character of Greece today is of a residential suburb with modern industry and commerce. The official flag of the Town of Greece was adopted at a meeting of the Town Council on August 17, 1954. Centered in a field of white is a circular emblem, designed by J. S. Perticone depicting the old lighthouse at the mouth of the Genesee River which was built in 1822 - the same year the Town was established. The circle represents the shield of the warriors of the Ancient Greece and the border is of characteristic Greek design. Lightning flashes symbolize energy and strength and the colors - terra cotta, golden yellow and black - are those used in old Greek pottery and artistic decorations.

properties.name: Holland (Michigan)
properties.description: Posted by HiveThe community was named by Dutch immigrants who settled here in 1847. Although not the only \'Holland\' in Michigan, I chose this one for it\'s proximity to Zeeland (dutch for sea land).

properties.name: Lebanon (Tennessee)
properties.description: Posted by Baostarlebanon, tennesseeLebanon is a city in Wilson County, Tennessee, in the United States. Not sure where it got its namesake but the Arabic country in the Middle East comes to mind.

properties.name: Morocco (Indiana)
properties.description: Posted by Hivemorocco, indianaAncestries: German (27.3%), Irish (14.9%), English (13.8%), United States (10.1%), French (4.5%), Swedish (4.3%).

properties.name: Turkey (Texas)
properties.description: Posted by HiveTurkey, TexasNot named after the nation, but rather after the wild turkeys found near a creek here, this city of 500 carries the subtitle, "Western Swing Capital of the World"
